text: <@U0208DGLY87> - It's hyper-accurate and focused on exactly what the next year would look like based on competitors and current analytics fro the client. I've had clients use this data not only in working with me, but also in internal presentations to double their team size or add a TON of budget that leadership told them wasn't available.

text:
how do you structure your content team?
• do you provide content services to other teams (product, demand gen, etc)
• do you place content marketers on those teams? in which case your org chart is more like a matrix with a central content lead
• do you focus on growth content (i.e. growing traffic, MQLSs, etc) then outsource everything else?
this seems to be a common problem, very curious how folks think about this.

text: Hi, Cassandra. Rather than tying the licenses into a specific person's account, you can ask your IT team to set up a team email for you. In the past, we've often had all our licenses going to <mailto:marketing@company.com|marketing@company.com> or similar so that access isn't lost as roles transition in/out. You could also look at using Okta for tracking who has access to what and making logging in/out easier. Hope that helps!

text:
should i create and publish case study-style blog posts?

i’m wary of diluting our blog with “customer feature” posts (aka case studies) because it’s very self serving and i feel like that detracts from the blog’s primary mission, which is helpful content.

Currently debating this internally and i seem to be the only one who feels like this is a problem. am i off-base?

elements.text:
should i create and publish case study-style blog posts?

i’m wary of diluting our blog with “customer feature” posts (aka case studies) because it’s very self serving and i feel like that detracts from the blog’s primary mission, which is helpful content.

Currently debating this internally and i seem to be the only one who feels like this is a problem. am i off-base?

text: I think you should consider creating a sub-category for this in your blog, and set it in a way that when you publish inside this subcategory, it doesn't get published in the blog too. For instance, if you have a blog, you can create a subcategory like Case studies, or probably have a resources page with "blog" and "Case studies" or "any name you decide to give this" as subcategories. I'm sure this will help you keep a clean blog, but i'm sure it'll also depend on your blog.

elements.text: I think you should consider creating a sub-category for this in your blog, and set it in a way that when you publish inside this subcategory, it doesn't get published in the blog too. For instance, if you have a blog, you can create a subcategory like Case studies, or probably have a resources page with "blog" and "Case studies" or "any name you decide to give this" as subcategories. I'm sure this will help you keep a clean blog, but i'm sure it'll also depend on your blog.

text: I think it depends! If there is a way to position the stories with takeaways anyone could benefit from (not just people using the product), I think it can be valuable. Or the blog could be used to interview/profile the contact at the customer account so it’s less “case study” and more about their day-to-day, challenges, successes, things they’ve learned, etc. and maybe a small product plug if you need to tie it back

elements.text: I think it depends! If there is a way to position the stories with takeaways anyone could benefit from (not just people using the product), I think it can be valuable. Or the blog could be used to interview/profile the contact at the customer account so it’s less “case study” and more about their day-to-day, challenges, successes, things they’ve learned, etc. and maybe a small product plug if you need to tie it back

text: You can highlight specific case studies that tie into your regular blog post. For example, if you're writing about how your product solves A. And can help people solve A with/without your product. You can add a brief section from a case study

elements.text: You can highlight specific case studies that tie into your regular blog post. For example, if you're writing about how your product solves A. And can help people solve A with/without your product. You can add a brief section from a case study

text:
:bulb: Would love to see you develop content on this.

I don't think there's any "right" answer, but would be cool to see the different permutations of this from different orgs...

Right now, we have two content marketers and a designer. We're focused on growth content across our key channels (blog, gated offers, certificate courses), sales enablement (case studies, primarily), and distribution (email, organic social). We do all writing in-house.

Where I'd like to go this year in building out our team:
• Each Content Marketing Manager is a DRI (directly responsible individual) for a content type. Example: CMM for blog and SEO; CMM for acquisition content. But they still contribute across all content type. This gives them a revenue metric/set of metrics to own around their channel.
• A new Content Editorial Manager is the "managing editor" and the captain of our editorial processes/workflows.
• Content Mktg Specialists own distribution (ex: social, email) and support with content creation.
• All content creators support product marketing, demand gen, sales on a case-by-case basis

elements.text:
Would love to see you develop content on this.

I don't think there's any "right" answer, but would be cool to see the different permutations of this from different orgs...

Right now, we have two content marketers and a designer. We're focused on growth content across our key channels (blog, gated offers, certificate courses), sales enablement (case studies, primarily), and distribution (email, organic social). We do all writing in-house.

Where I'd like to go this year in building out our team:

Each Content Marketing Manager is a DRI (directly responsible individual) for a content type. Example: CMM for blog and SEO; CMM for acquisition content. But they still contribute across all content type. This gives them a revenue metric/set of metrics to own around their channel.
A new Content Editorial Manager is the "managing editor" and the captain of our editorial processes/workflows.
Content Mktg Specialists own distribution (ex: social, email) and support with content creation.
All content creators support product marketing, demand gen, sales on a case-by-case basis

text:
• We provide support for Demand Gen predominantly and Product Marketing as a secondary. Alongside SEO-focused content, we write content to support demand gen campaigns. We’ve gotten to a point in our maturity where we often can recommend content to their campaigns rather than writing something new every time. Our content goes into email drips, lead ads, BDR cadences, webinars that source meetings. This works well for us because we report on meetings/demo requests generated from SEO and Demand Gen reports on the same metrics for their reporting. 
• We work in tandem with product marketing when there is a product/feature that is signfiicant enough that we can promote strategy behind it from a content perspective. Product Marketing owns collateral like one-pagers. So for example, when we launched texting features for grassroots advocacy campaigns (Text JOIN to sign up for Students for Climate), Product Marketing owned one-pagers, slide decks, etc. and content marketing wrote pieces on “How to Grow Your Grassroots Audience” with texting being a key strategy in the blog. 
• To some extent we create content for sales enablement, but to this point it hasn’t been our primary focus. By sales enablement, I mean post-demo pre-close (our average sales cycle is ~60-90 days). As we seek to move up market, we’re increasing efforts here.
• Our content team by the end of the half will be 3 total - myself managing the team, one content associate focused on industry-specific content (to support ABM campaigns with Demand Gen) and one focused on longer form pieces (lead gen data reports, sales enablement e-books, etc.)
• Our outsourcing is kind of all over the place. We’re trying to outsource top of funnel awareness content because we’re in a niche industry that has a high learning curve for speaking with authority. But we’re also trying to outsource more in-depth lead gen reports with data researchers

elements.text: We provide support for Demand Gen predominantly and Product Marketing as a secondary. Alongside SEO-focused content, we write content to support demand gen campaigns. We’ve gotten to a point in our maturity where we often can recommend content to their campaigns rather than writing something new every time. Our content goes into email drips, lead ads, BDR cadences, webinars that source meetings. This works well for us because we report on meetings/demo requests generated from SEO and Demand Gen reports on the same metrics for their reporting.

We work in tandem with product marketing when there is a product/feature that is signfiicant enough that we can promote strategy behind it from a content perspective. Product Marketing owns collateral like one-pagers. So for example, when we launched texting features for grassroots advocacy campaigns (Text JOIN to sign up for Students for Climate), Product Marketing owned one-pagers, slide decks, etc. and content marketing wrote pieces on “How to Grow Your Grassroots Audience” with texting being a key strategy in the blog.

To some extent we create content for sales enablement, but to this point it hasn’t been our primary focus. By sales enablement, I mean post-demo pre-close (our average sales cycle is ~60-90 days). As we seek to move up market, we’re increasing efforts here.

Our content team by the end of the half will be 3 total - myself managing the team, one content associate focused on industry-specific content (to support ABM campaigns with Demand Gen) and one focused on longer form pieces (lead gen data reports, sales enablement e-books, etc.)

Our outsourcing is kind of all over the place. We’re trying to outsource top of funnel awareness content because we’re in a niche industry that has a high learning curve for speaking with authority. But we’re also trying to outsource more in-depth lead gen reports with data researchers

text: Lots of good thoughts already. I would say another way to look at this - is to give your case studies more of a narrative or story of transition with lots of anecdotes and examples.

elements.text: Lots of good thoughts already. I would say another way to look at this - is to give your case studies more of a narrative or story of transition with lots of anecdotes and examples.

text: We publish articles and ebooks as part of a "library" of thought-leadership resources, company announcements and news in a Company Blog, and case studies in a 3rd separate collection that lives primarily on our Customers page. This keeps all content clustered with like content.

elements.text: We publish articles and ebooks as part of a "library" of thought-leadership resources, company announcements and news in a Company Blog, and case studies in a 3rd separate collection that lives primarily on our Customers page. This keeps all content clustered with like content.
